title: How to Make Bubble Tea

steps.headline: Pre-soak the pearls for a few hours if you want them tender all the way through, rather than soft on the outside and chewy on the inside (which is how most people prefer them).
Measure 7 parts water to 1 part tapioca pearls.
steps.description: Bring the water to a rolling boil.

steps.headline: Add the pearls and stir them to make sure they don't stick to the bottom.
When the pearls float to the top, cover the pot and keep the water at a rolling boil for 30 minutes.
Remove from heat and let the pearls sit covered for 30 minutes.
Rinse the pearls with lukewarm or cold water.
Sweeten the pearls with honey or the following sugar syrup to taste (which can also be used to sweeten the drink).
steps.description: Mix one cup of white sugar, one cup of brown sugar, and two cups of water in a pot. Bring to a boil, then immediately remove from heat. Let cool.

steps.headline: Use them immediately, or cover them and put them in the fridge for no more than 4 days (or else they will get too mushy).
steps.description: When you want to use them, boil a cup of water and put the tapioca pearls in it for a few minutes to warm them.

methods.name: Soak in Sugar Water Instead of Cooking

steps.headline: Follow the steps in the first method for how to cook the tapioca pearls.
Prepare the "sugar water".
steps.description: Mix 100ml of hot water with 100g of brown sugar (if you don’t have any brown sugar you can use white sugar and honey).

steps.headline: Stir this until the sugar is dissolved.
steps.description: Then pour it into a bowl.

steps.headline: Let the tapioca balls sit for 15 minutes in the sugar water.
Now they're ready to serve.

steps.headline: Make the tea.
steps.description: Bubble tea was traditionally made with black tea, but you can use green, chai, yerba  mate, or any kind of tea. You can even use coffee!

steps.headline: Mix 3/4 cup of tea with 2 tablespoons of cream and 1 tablespoon of sugar syrup (as directed above) in a shaker.
steps.description: You can substitute the cream with soy milk, milk, half and half, sweetened condensed milk, or non dairy creamer.

steps.headline: Add ice, cover the shaker, and shake the mixture until it gets frothy.
steps.description: (The bubbles formed by shaking are what the tea was named after, although most people assume it's because the tapioca pearls look like bubbles!)

steps.headline: Put 3-4 tablespoons of cooked tapioca pearls in a glass and pour in the mixture.

text:
Preparing Tapioca Pearls (Boba) Pre-soak the pearls for a few hours if you want them tender all the way through, rather than soft on the outside and chewy on the inside (which is how most people prefer them).  Measure 7 parts water to 1 part tapioca pearls. Bring the water to a rolling boil. Add the pearls and stir them to make sure they don't stick to the bottom.  When the pearls float to the top, cover the pot and keep the water at a rolling boil for 30 minutes. Stir every 10 minutes. Remove from heat and let the pearls sit covered for 30 minutes.  Rinse the pearls with lukewarm or cold water.  Sweeten the pearls with honey or the following sugar syrup to taste (which can also be used to sweeten the drink). Mix one cup of white sugar, one cup of brown sugar, and two cups of water in a pot. Bring to a boil, then immediately remove from heat. Let cool. Use them immediately, or cover them and put them in the fridge for no more than 4 days (or else they will get too mushy). When you want to use them, boil a cup of water and put the tapioca pearls in it for a few minutes to warm them. Soak in Sugar Water Instead of Cooking Follow the steps in the first method for how to cook the tapioca pearls. Rinse them off. Prepare the "sugar water". Mix 100ml of hot water with 100g of brown sugar (if you don’t have any brown sugar you can use white sugar and honey). Stir this until the sugar is dissolved. Then pour it into a bowl. Let the tapioca balls sit for 15 minutes in the sugar water.  Now they're ready to serve.  Traditional Milk Tea[2]

Mix 3/4 cup of tea with 2 tablespoons of cream and 1 tablespoon of sugar syrup (as directed above) in a shaker. You can substitute the cream with soy milk, milk, half and half, sweetened condensed milk, or non dairy creamer. Add ice, cover the shaker, and shake the mixture until it gets frothy. (The bubbles formed by shaking are what the tea was named after, although most people assume it's because the tapioca pearls look like bubbles!) Put 3-4 tablespoons of cooked tapioca pearls in a glass and pour in the mixture.  Stir and drink!  Fruit Bubble Tea Combine ice, fresh fruit (or fruit juice), sweetener (e.g. sugar syrup) and cream (or substitute) in a blender until smooth. The consistency and proportions should be adjusted to taste. Put 3-4 tablespoons of cooked tapioca pearls in a glass and pour the fruity mixture over them.  Stir and drink!
